summary: The US and UK markets experienced a record day on Wall Street, with both the S&P and Nasdaq reaching record highs due to rising CPI (CPI), despite expectations that the Fed would cut its rate rate in September. The S &P 500 ended the day higher by more than 70 points, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up by 1.4% and the Nasdaq composite by about 1.3%. Despite this, David Gura and Vonnie Quinn suggest that there is still a lot of data ahead for the next Fed meeting, including policy speeches from Jackson Hole. The news of the rising CPI also led to optimism about the possibility of the Fed starting reducing the rate. Meanwhile, Delta Airlines saw a 10% increase in its stock performance, with Delta Airlines' stock alone gaining 10% in the session. All sectors in the S & P 500 ended in the green.
shortSummary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq hit record highs as CPI rose, driven by optimism and a raft of positive data, with potential rate cuts expected before the next Fed meeting.
argos_summary: The trading day ended with the S&P 500 reaching a record high, up 1%, driven by optimism following a CPI report indicating manageable inflation levels. Market expectations are leaning towards potential rate cuts by the Federal Reserve in September, with a 94% chance of a 25 basis point cut. Airline stocks performed notably well, with gains attributed to rising fares, while President Trump's comments on tariffs and corporate leadership have raised concerns about potential market risks.
